skos:Concept.skos:definition: The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and may radiate sound without requiring stretched membranes or strings.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to itssolidity and elasticity, vibrates and may radiate sound without requiring stretched membranes or strings. The instrument is made to vibrate by being struck.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and may radiate sound without requiring stretched membranes or strings. The instrument is made to vibrate by being struck. The player executes the movement of striking; whether by mechanical intermediate devices, beaters, keyboards, or by pulling ropes, etc., is immaterial; it is definitive that the player can apply clearly defined individual strokes and that the instrument itself is equipped for this kind of percussion.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to itssolidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when struck. The player strikes together two or more complementary sonorous parts to create clearly defined individual strokes.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when struck. The player strikes together two or more sonorous sticks; to create clearly defined individual strokes. Annam, India, Marshall Islands.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when struck. The player strikes together two or more sonorous plaques to create clearly defined individual strokes. China, India.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when struck. The player strikes together two or more sonorous plaques to create clearly defined individual strokes. Burma.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when struck. The player strikes together two or more sonorous vessels to create clearly defined individual strokes. Even a slight hollow in the surface of a board counts as a vessel.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when struck. The player strikes together two or more sonorous vessel clappers to create clearly defined individual strokes. The clappers are either naturally or artificially hollowed out.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when struck. Cymbals are metal vessel clappers with everted rims, struck together by the player to create clearly defined individual strokes.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when struck. The player strikes together two or more metal bells to create clearly defined individual strokes. Nigeria.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and may radiate sound when struck either with a non-sonorous object (hand, stick, striker) or against a non-sonorous object (human body, the ground). The player creates clearly defined individual strokes.

Instruments in the form of sticks, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and may radiate sound when struck either with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects (human body, the ground). The player creates clearly defined individual strokes.

An instrument in the form of a stick, owing to the solidity and elasticity of its substance, vibrates and may radiate sound when struck either with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects (human body, the ground). The player creates clearly defined individual strokes. Japan, Annam, Balkans. Also the triangle.

Instruments in the form of sets of sticks, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and may radiate sound when struck either with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects (human body, the ground). Several percussion sticks of different pitches are combined to form a single instrument. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes. All xylophones.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 111.212-8 Sets of percussion sticks with keyboard
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Instruments in the form of sets of sticks, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and may radiate sound when struck either with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects (human body, the ground). Several percussion sticks of different pitches are combined to form a single instrument. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes. With keyboard.

Instruments in the form of plaques, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck either with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes.

AAn instrument in the form of a plaque, owing to the solidity and elasticity of its substance, vibrates and radiates sound when struck either with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes. In the oriental Christian Church.

Instruments in the form of sets of plaques, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck either with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects. Several percussion plaques of different pitches are combined to form a single instrument. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes. Lithophone (China), and most metallophones.

Instruments in the form of tubes, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck either with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects (human body, the ground). The player creates clearly defined individual strokes.

An instrument in the form of a tube, owing to the solidity and elasticity of its substance, vibrates and radiates sound when struck either with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects (human body, the ground). The player creates clearly defined individual strokes. This group does not include slit drums, which are a sub-group of bells, 111.243.

Instruments in the form of sets of tubes, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck either with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects (human body, the ground). Several percussion tubes of different pitches are combined to form a single instrument. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes. Tubaphon, tubular xylophone.

Instruments in the form of vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck either with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes.

Metal percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker). The vibration is strongest near the vertex of the struck surface. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes.

Individual metal percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker). The vibration is strongest near the vertex of the struck surface. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes. S. and E. Asia. This group includes the so-called metal drums, or rather kettle-gongs.

Metal percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker). The vibration is strongest near the vertex. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes.

Metal percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker). The struck surface of the vessel is divided to create notes of different pitches, and the vibration is strongest near the vertex of each struck section. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes. Steel drums, Caribbean.

Sets of metal percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker). The vibration is strongest near the vertex of the struck surface. The gongs are tuned to different pitches. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes. [Gong chimes] S.E.Asia.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 111.241.21 Sets of bossed and flat gongs
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of metal percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker). The vibration is strongest near the vertex. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes. S.E. Asia, E. Asia

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 111.241.22 Sets of gongs with divided surface
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of metal percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker). The struck surface is divided to create notes of different pitches and the vibration is strongest near the vertex of each struck section. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes. Steel drums, Caribbean.

Percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck either with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects. The vibration is weakest near the vertex of the struck surface. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes.

Individual percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck either with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects. The vibration is weakest near the vertex of the struck surface. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes.

Individual percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker). The cup is placed on the palm of the hand or on a cushion; its mouth faces upwards. The vibration is weakest near the crown. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes. China, Indo-China, Japan.

Individual percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck either with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects. The vibration is weakest near the apex from which the instrument is suspended. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 111.242.121 (Individual) suspended bells struck from the outside
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Individual percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker). The vibration is weakest near the apex from which the instrument is suspended. The bell has no internal striker; the player creates clearly defined individual strokes on its external surface, using a separate beater.

Individual percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck with non-sonorous objects. The vibration is weakest near the apex from which the instrument is suspended. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes using the striker (clapper) attached inside the bell.

Individual percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck with non-sonorous objects. The vibration is weakest near the apex from which the instrument is suspended. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes on the exterior surface of the bell, using an attached external striker (clapper).

Sets of percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck either with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects. The vibration is weakest near the vertex of the struck surface. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes. [chimes].

Sets of percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker). The cup of each bell is placed on the palm of the hand or on a cushion; its mouth faces upwards. The vibration is weakest near the crown. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes. China, Japan.

Sets of individual percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck either with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects. The vibration is weakest near the apex from which each instrument is suspended. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 111.242.221 (Sets of) suspended bells struck from the outside
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker). The vibration is weakest near the apex from which each instrument is suspended. The bells have no internal strikers; the player creates clearly defined individual strokes on their exterior surfaces, using external beaters.

Sets of percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck either with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker). The vibration is weakest near the apex from which each instrument is suspended. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes using the strikers (clappers) attached inside the bells.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 111.242.223 (Sets of) bells with attached external clappers
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker). The vibration is weakest near the apex from which each instrument is suspended. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes on the exterior surfaces of the bells, using attached external strikers (clappers).

Wooden percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck with a non-sonorous object (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects. The vessels have a longitudinal slit. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes on the external surface of the instrument.

Wooden percussion vessels, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects. The instruments have a wide longitudinal mouth. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes on the external surface of the instrument. Some forms of slit drum such as Fijian lali where the whole mouth is open.

Sonorous boulders, owing to the solidity and elasticity of their substance, vibrate and radiate sound when struck either with non-sonorous objects (hand, stick, striker) or against non-sonorous objects. The player creates clearly defined individual strokes. Rock gongs.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and may radiate sound without requiring stretched membranes or strings. The instrument is made to vibrate by being struck. The player does not go through the movement of striking; percussion results indirectly through some other movement by the player. The intention is to yield clusters of sounds or noises, and not to let individual strokes be perceived.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when struck. Percussion results indirectly through a shaking movement executed by the player. The intention is to yield clusters of sounds or noises, and not to let individual strokes be perceived.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when struck. Percussion results indirectly through a shaking movement executed by the player. Perforated idiophones are mounted together, and shaken to strike against each other. The intention is to yield clusters of sounds or noises, and not to let individual strokes be perceived.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when struck. Percussion results indirectly through a shaking movement executed by the player. Rattling objects are strung in rows on a cord. The intention is to yield clusters of sounds or noises, and not to let individual strokes be perceived. Necklaces with rows of shells.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when struck. Percussion results indirectly through a shaking movement executed by the player. Rattling objects are strung on a bar (or ring). The intention is to yield clusters of sounds or noises, and not to let individual strokes be perceived. Sistrum with rings.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when struck. Percussion results indirectly through a shaking movement executed by the player. Rattling objects are attached to a carrier against which they strike. The intention is to yield clusters of sounds or noises, and not to let individual strokes be perceived.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when struck. Percussion results indirectly through a shaking movement executed by the player. Rattling objects are hung from a frame. The intention is to yield clusters of sounds or noises, and not to let individual strokes be perceived. Dancing shield with rattling rings.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when struck. Percussion results indirectly through a shaking movement executed by the player. Non-sonorous objects slide to and fro in the slots of the sonorous object so that the latter is made to vibrate; or sonorous objects slide to and fro in the slots of a non-sonorous object, to be set in vibration by the impacts. The intention is to yield clusters of sounds or noises, and not to let individual strokes be perceived. Anklung, sistrum with rods.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when struck. Percussion results indirectly through a shaking movement executed by the player. Rattling objects are enclosed in a vessel or are attached to a net slipped over a vessel. They strike against each other or against the walls of the vessel, or usually against both. The intention is to yield clusters of sounds or noises, and not to let individual strokes be perceived. Fruit shells with seeds, pellet bells enclosing loose percussion pellets.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when scraped. The player causes a scraping movement directly or indirectly. A non-sonorous object moves along the notched surface of a sonorous object, to be alternately lifted off the teeth and flicked against them; or an elastic sonorous object moves along the surface of a notched non-sonorous object to cause a series of impacts. This group must not be confused with that of friction idiophones.
The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when scraped. A notched stick is scraped with a little stick.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when scraped. A notched stick is scraped with a little stick. The notched stick has no resonator. S. America, India (notched musical bow), Congo.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when scraped. A notched stick is scraped with a little stick. The notched stick has an attached resonator. Usumbara, E. Asia (tiger).
The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when scraped. A sonorous notched tube is scraped with a non-sonorous stick. S. India.
The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when scraped. The corrugated surface of a vessel is scraped. S. America, Congo region.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when scraped. There is a cog wheel, whose axle serves as the handle, and a tongue fixed in a frame which is free to turn on the handle; when whirled, the tongue strikes the teeth of the wheel one after another. Europe, India.
The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when scraped. A notched board is scraped with a stick. Jazz washboard.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound when struck. Instruments are in the shape of two springy arms connected at one end and touching at the other; in some instances the arms are forced apart by a little stick, to jingle or vibrate on recoil. China (huan t'u), Malacca, Persia (qasik), Balkans.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to itssolidity and elasticity, vibrates and may radiate sound without requiring stretched membranes or strings. The instrument is made to vibrate by being struck. Mechanically driven.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. Lamellae, i.e. elastic plaques, fixed at one end, are flexed and then released to return to their position of rest.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 121 Lamellaphones (or plucked idiophones) in the form of a frame
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. Lamellae, i.e. elastic plaques, fixed at one end, are flexed and then released to return to their position of rest. The lamellae vibrate within a frame or hoop.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. A lamella, i.e. elastic plaque, fixed at one end, is flexed and then released to return to its position of rest. The lamella is carved in the surface of a fruit shell, which serves as resonator. Melanesia (cricri).

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. A lamella, i.e. elastic plaque, fixed at one end, is flexed and then released to return to its position of rest. The lamella is mounted in a rod- or plaque-shaped frame and depends on the players mouth cavity for resonance. Trumps (also known as jew's harps).

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. A lamella, i.e. elastic plaque, fixed at one end, is flexed and then released to return to its position of rest. The lamella is carved within a rod- or plaque-shaped frame and depends on the players mouth cavity for resonance. The base of the lamella remains joined to the frame. India, Indonesia, Melanesia.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. A lamella, i.e. elastic plaque, fixed at one end, is flexed and then released to return to its position of rest. The lamella is a separate piece from the rod- or plaque-shaped frame on which it is mounted. The instrument depends on the players mouth cavity for resonance.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. In an individual guimbarde a lamella, i.e. elastic plaque, fixed at one end, is flexed and then released to return to its position of rest. The lamella is a separate piece from the rod- or plaque-shaped frame on which it is mounted. The instrument depends on the players mouth cavity for resonance. Europe, India, China.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. A lamella, i.e. elastic plaque, fixed at one end, is flexed and then released to return to its position of rest. The lamella is a separate piece from the rod- or plaque-shaped frame on which it is mounted. Several heteroglot guimbardes of different pitches are combined to form a single instrument that depends on the players mouth cavity for resonance. Aura.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 122 Lamellaphones (or plucked idiophones) in board- or comb-form
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. Lamellae, i.e. elastic plaques, fixed at one end, are flexed and then released to return to their position of rest. The lamellae are attached to a board or cut out from a board like the teeth of a comb.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 122.1 Lamellaphones (or plucked idiophones) with laced-on, or hooked-in lamellae
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. Lamellae, i.e. elastic plaques, fixed at one end, are flexed and then released to return to their position of rest. The lamellae are laced on or hooked into a board.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 122.11 Lamellaphones (or plucked idiophones) with laced-on, or hooked-in lamellae, without resonator
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. Lamellae, i.e. elastic plaques, fixed at one end, are flexed and then released to return to their position of rest. The lamellae are laced on or hooked into a board. The instrument has no resonator.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 122.12 Lamellaphones (or plucked idiophones) with laced-on, or hooked-in lamellae, with resonator
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. Lamellae, i.e. elastic plaques, fixed at one end, are flexed and then released to return to their position of rest. The lamellae are laced on or hooked into a board. The instrument has a bowl or an integral box below the board, functioning as a resonator.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 122.2 Lamellaphones (or plucked idiophones) with cut-out lamellae
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. Lamellae, i.e. elastic plaques, fixed at one end, are flexed and then released to return to their position of rest. The lamellae are of steel and are cut out in the form of a comb. Pins on a cylinder, or projections on a disc, pluck the lamellae. (Musical boxes).

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 122.2-8 Lamellaphones (or plucked idiophones) with cut-out lamellae with keyboard
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. Lamellae, i.e. elastic plaques, fixed at one end, are flexed and then released to return to their position of rest. The lamellae are of steel and are cut out in the form of a comb. Pins on a cylinder, or projections on a disc, pluck the lamellae. With keyboard.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 122.2-9 Mechanically driven lamellaphones (or plucked idiophones) with cut-out lamellae
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. Lamellae, i.e. elastic plaques, fixed at one end, are flexed and then released to return to their position of rest. The lamellae are of steel and are cut out in the form of a comb. Pins on a cylinder, or projections on a disc, pluck the lamellae. Mechanically driven.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. Lamellae, i.e. elastic plaques, fixed at one end, are flexed and then released to return to their position of rest. With keyboard.
The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by friction.
The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is in the form of a stick, and is made to vibrate by friction.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, is made to vibrate and radiate sound by friction. The instrument consists of an individual friction stick. Sandpaper blocks.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by friction. The vibrating material consists of an individual vessel. Mechanically driven.
The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, is made to vibrate and radiate sound by friction. The instrument is formed of a set of friction sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 131.21 Sets of friction sticks with direct friction
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, is made to vibrate and radiate sound by direct friction. The instrument is formed of a set of sticks that are rubbed. Nail fiddle, nail piano, Stockspiele.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 131.22 Sets of friction sticks with indirect friction
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, is made to vibrate and radiate sound by indirect friction. A set of sticks is connected with others that are rubbed and, by transmitting their longitudinal vibration, stimulate transverse vibration in the former. Chladnis euphon.
The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by friction. The vibrating material consists of plaques.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by friction. The vibrating material consists of an individual plaque.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by friction. The vibrating material consists of a set of plaques
The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is in the form of a vessel, and is made to vibrate by friction.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by friction. The vibrating material consists of an individual vessel. Brazil (tortoise shell).

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by friction. The vibrating material consists of a set of vessels. Verillon (glass armonica).

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 133.2-9 Mechanically driven sets of friction vessels
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by friction. The vibrating material consists of a set of vessels. Mechanically driven.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by friction. The vibrating material consists of a stretched sheet. Theatrical wind machine.
The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by being blown upon.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by being blown upon. The vibrating material consists of sticks.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by being blown upon. The vibrating material consists of an individual stick. Unknown.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by being blown upon. The vibrating material consists of a set of blown sticks. Aeolsklavier.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by being blown upon. The vibrating material consists of blown plaques.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by being blown upon. The vibrating material consists of individual blown plaques. Unknown.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by being blown upon. The vibrating material consists of a set of blown plaques. Piano chanteur.
The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The vibrating material consists of a flexible sheet of metal.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by friction. The vibrating material consists of a flexible sheet of metal.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by being struck directly. The vibrating material consists of a flexible sheet of metal. Theatrical thunder sheet played with a hammer.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by being shaken. The vibrating material consists of a flexible sheet of metal. Theatrical thunder sheet played without a hammer.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 154 Metal sheet shaken and indirectly struck
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The instrument is made to vibrate by being shaken and indirectly struck. The vibrating material consists of a flexible sheet of metal. Flexatone.

The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, vibrates and radiates sound. The vibrating material consists of a semi-rigid diaphragm. The diaphragm is flexed when a string passing through its centre is pulled, before returning to rest. England, modified watering can rose or string-and-yoghurt pot toy imitating a clucking cockerel.
The sound is excited by tightly-stretched membranes.
Tightly stretched membranes are struck.
The player executes the movement of striking tightly stretched membranes. This includes striking by any intermediate devices, such as beaters, keyboards, etc. Drums that are shaken are excluded.

Drums with single tightly stretched membranes enclosing drum bodies in the form of vessels that are curvilinear or rectilinear in profile. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. Kettledrums.

An individual drum with a single tightly stretched membrane enclosing a drum body in the form of a vessel that is curvilinear or rectilinear in profile. The membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. European timpani.

An individual drum with a single tightly stretched membrane enclosing a drum body in the form of a vessel that is curvilinear or rectilinear in profile. The membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane laced to drum. With tension loops. The cords are laced in a zigzag: every pair of strings is caught together with a small ring or loop. India.

An individual drum with a single tightly stretched membrane enclosing a drum body in the form of a vessel that is curvilinear or rectilinear in profile. The membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane laced to drum. Cord-and-hide bracing. The cords are laced at the lower end to a non-sonorous piece of hide.

An individual drum with a single tightly stretched membrane enclosing a drum body in the form of a vessel that is curvilinear or rectilinear in profile. The membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane laced to drum. Cord-and-belt bracing. The cords are laced at the lower end to a belt of different material. India.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.11-92 (Separate) vessel drums with membrane lapped onto a hoop
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a single tightly stretched membrane enclosing a drum body in the form of a vessel that is curvilinear or rectilinear in profile. The membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane lapped onto a hoop.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.11-9211 (Separate) vessel drums with membrane lapped onto a hoop with pedal mechanism
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a single tightly stretched membrane enclosing a drum body in the form of a vessel that is curvilinear or rectilinear in profile. The membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane lapped onto a hoop. With mechanism; with pedals.

Joined sets of drums with single tightly stretched membranes enclosing drum bodies in the form of vessels that are curvilinear or rectilinear in profile. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. West Asian permanently joined pairs of kettledrums.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.12-812 Sets of kettledrums with tension loops
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Joined sets of drums with single tightly stretched membranes enclosing drum bodies in the form of vessels that are curvilinear or rectilinear in profile. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. West Asian permanently joined pairs of kettledrums. With membrane laced to drum. With tension loops. The cords are laced in a zigzag: every pair of strings is caught together with a small ring or loop. India.
Drums with tubular bodies and tightly stretched membranes enclosing one or both ends. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums with tubular bodies that have essentially the same diameter at the middle and the ends; whether or not the ends taper slightly or have projecting discs, is immaterial. Tightly stretched membranes enclose one or both ends, and are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums with tubular bodies that have the same diameter at the middle and the ends. These drums have single tightly stretched membranes and the opposite ends are open. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

An individual drum with a tubular body that has the same diameter at the middle and the ends. The drum body is enclosed at one end by a single tightly stretched membrane and the opposite end is open. The membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. Malacca, now West Malaysia.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.211.1-7 Individual single-skin cylindrical drums with membrane nailed to drum
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a tubular body that has the same diameter at the middle and the ends. The drum body is enclosed at one end by a single tightly stretched membrane and the opposite end is open. The membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane nailed to drum.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.211.1-92 Individual single-skin cylindrical drums with membrane lapped onto a hoop
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a tubular body that has the same diameter at the middle and the ends. The drum body is enclosed at one end by a single tightly stretched membrane and the opposite end is open. The membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane lapped onto a hoop.

Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have the same diameter at the middle and the ends. Each drum body is enclosed at one end by a single tightly stretched membrane, and the opposite end is open. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums with tubular bodies that have the same diameter at the middle and the ends. The drum bodies are enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

An individual drum with a tubular body that has the same diameter at the middle and the ends. The drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.212.11 Individual double-skin cylindrical drums, one skin used for playing
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a tubular body that has the same diameter at the middle and the ends. The drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. One membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. Europe; side drum, tenor drum, tambourin de Provence.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.212.11-92 Individual double-skin cylindrical drums, one skin used for playing with membrane lapped onto a hoop
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a tubular body that has a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. One membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane lapped onto a hoop.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.212.12 Individual double-skin cylindrical drums, both heads played
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a tubular body that has the same diameter at the middle and the ends. The drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. Both membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. Turkey davul, Europe bass drum in marching band.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.212.1-92 Individual double-skin cylindrical drums with membrane lapped onto a hoop
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a tubular body that has the same diameter at the middle and the ends. The drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane lapped onto a hoop.

Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have the same diameter at the middle and the ends. Each drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.212.21 Sets of double-skin cylindrical drums with single playing heads
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have the same diameter at the middle and the ends. Each drum body is enclosed at both ends by a tightly stretched membrane only one of which is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. Europe drum kit.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.212.22 Sets of double-skin cylindrical drums, both heads played
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have the same diameter at the middle and the ends. Each drum body is enclosed at either end by a tightly stretched membrane. Both membranes are directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums with barrel-shaped bodies, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. The outline of the body is curvilinear. Tightly stretched membranes enclose one or both ends, and are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums with barrel-shaped bodies, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. The drums have single tightly stretched membranes and the opposite ends are open. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

An individual drum with a barrel-shaped body, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. The drum body is enclosed at one end by a single tightly stretched membrane and the opposite end is open. The membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Sets of drums with barrel-shaped bodies, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. Each drum body is enclosed at one end by a single tightly stretched membrane, and the opposite end is open. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums with barrel-shaped bodies, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. The drum bodies are enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

An individual drum with a barrel-shaped body, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. The drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.222.11 Individual double-skin barrel drums, one skin used for playing
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a barrel-shaped body, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. The drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. One membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.222.12 Individual double-skin barrel drums, both heads played
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a barrel-shaped body, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. The drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. Both membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.222.1-7 Individual double-skin barrel drums with membrane nailed to drum
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a barrel-shaped body, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. The drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane nailed to drum.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.222.1-813 Individual double-skin barrel drums with wedge-bracing
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a barrel-shaped body, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. The drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane laced to drum, with wedge-bracing.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.222.1-86 Individual double-skin barrel drums with cord-and-peg bracing
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a barrel-shaped body, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. The drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane laced to drum.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.222.1-92 Individual double-skin barrel drums with membrane lapped onto a hoop
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a barrel-shaped body, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. The drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane lapped onto a hoop.

Sets of drums with barrel-shaped bodies, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. Each drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.222.21 Sets of double-skin barrel drums with single playing heads
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of drums with barrel-shaped bodies, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. Each drum body is enclosed at both ends by a tightly stretched membrane only one of which is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.222.22 Sets of double-skin barrel drums, both heads played
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of drums with barrel-shaped bodies, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. Each drum body is enclosed at either end by a tightly stretched membrane. Both membranes are directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums with tubular bodies that have a larger diameter at the middle than at the ends. The drum bodies are rectilinear, with an angular profile. Tightly stretched membranes enclose one or both ends, and are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. India (mrdanga, pakhavaja).

Drums with tubular bodies that have a larger diameter at the middle than at the ends. The drum bodies are rectilinear, with an angular profile. They have single tightly stretched membranes and the opposite ends are open. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

An individual drum with a tubular body that has a larger diameter at the middle than at the ends. The drum body is rectilinear, with an angular profile. It is enclosed at one end by a single tightly stretched membrane and the opposite end is open. The membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have a larger diameter at the middle than at the ends. The drum bodies are rectilinear, with an angular profile. Each drum body is enclosed at one end by a single tightly stretched membrane, and the opposite end is open. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums with tubular bodies that have a larger diameter at the middle than at the ends. The drum bodies are rectilinear, with an angular profile. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

An individual drum with a tubular body that has a larger diameter at the middle than at the ends. The drum body is rectilinear, with an angular profile. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.232.11 Individual double-skin double-conical drums, one skin used for playing
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a tubular body that has a larger diameter at the middle than at the ends. The drum body is rectilinear, with an angular profile. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. One membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.232.12 Individual double-skin double-conical drums, both heads played
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a tubular body that has a larger diameter at the middle than at the ends. The drum body is rectilinear, with an angular profile. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. Both membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have a larger diameter at the middle than at the ends. The drum bodies are rectilinear, with an angular profile. Tightly stretched membranes enclose each drum body at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.232.21 Sets of double-skin double-conical drums with single playing heads
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have a larger diameter at the middle than at the ends. The drum bodies are rectilinear, with an angular profile. They are enclosed at both ends by a tightly stretched membrane only one of which is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.232.22 Sets of double-skin double-conical drums, both heads played
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have a larger diameter at the middle than at the ends. The drum bodies are rectilinear, with an angular profile. They are enclosed at both ends by a tightly stretched membrane. Both membranes are directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums with tubular bodies that have a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose one or both ends, and are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. Asia, Melanesia, E. Africa.

Drums with tubular bodies that have a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. These drums have single tightly stretched membranes and the opposite ends are open. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

An individual drum with a tubular body that has a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. It is enclosed at one end by a single tightly stretched membrane and the opposite end is open. The membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Each drum body is enclosed at one end by a single tightly stretched membrane, and the opposite end is open. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums with tubular bodies that have a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

An individual drum with a tubular body that has a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.242.11 Individual double-skin hourglass-shaped drums, one skin used for playing
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a tubular body that has a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. One membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.242.11-81 Individual double-skin hourglass-shaped drums, one skin used for playing with cord- (ribbon-) bracing
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a tubular body that has a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. One membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane laced to drum. Cord-(ribbon-) bracing. The cords are stretched from membrane to membrane or arranged in the form of a net.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.242.12 Individual double-skin hourglass-shaped drums, both heads played
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a tubular body that has a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. Both membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose each drum body at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.242.21 Sets of double-skin hourglass-shaped drums with single playing heads
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. They are enclosed at both ends by a tightly stretched membrane only one of which is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.242.22 Sets of double-skin hourglass-shaped drums, both heads played
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. Both membranes are directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums with tubular bodies in which the diameter at the ends differs considerably; some minor departures from strict conicity, inevitably met, are disregarded here. Tightly stretched membranes enclose one or both ends, and are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums with tubular bodies in which the diameter at the ends differs considerably. These drums have single tightly stretched membranes and the opposite ends are open. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

An individual drum with a tubular body in which the diameter at the ends differs considerably. It is enclosed at one end by a single tightly stretched membrane and the opposite end is open. The membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Sets of drums with tubular bodies in which the diameter at the ends differs considerably. Each drum body is enclosed at one end by a single tightly stretched membrane, and the opposite end is open. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums with tubular bodies in which the diameter at the ends differs considerably. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

An individual drum with a tubular body in which the diameter at the ends differs considerably. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.252.11 Individual double-skin conical drums, one skin used for playing
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a tubular body in which the diameter at the ends differs considerably. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. One membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.252.12 Individual double-skin conical drums, both heads played
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a tubular body in which the diameter at the ends differs considerably. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. Both membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.252.1-81 Individual double-skin conical drums with cord- (ribbon-) bracing
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a tubular body in which the diameter at the ends differs considerably. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane laced to drum. Cord-(ribbon-) bracing. The cords are stretched from membrane to membrane or arranged in the form of a net.

Sets of drums with tubular bodies in which the diameter at the ends differs considerably. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.252.21 Sets of double-skin conical drums with single playing heads
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of drums with tubular bodies in which the diameter at the ends differs considerably. Each drum body is enclosed at both ends by a tightly stretched membrane only one of which is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. Entenga drum chime.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.252.22 Sets of double-skin conical drums, both heads played
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of drums with tubular bodies in which the diameter at the ends differs considerably. Tightly stretched membranes enclose each drum body at either end. Both membranes are directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums with tubular bodies consisting of a main section which is either cup-shaped or cylindrical, and a slender stem. A tightly stretched membrane encloses the upper end, and is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.26-6 Single-skin goblet-shaped drums with membrane glued to drum
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Drums with tubular bodies consisting of a main section which is either cup-shaped or cylindrical, and a slender stem. A tightly stretched membrane encloses the upper end, and is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane glued to drum.

Drums with tubular bodies consisting of a cylindrical upper section and a conical lower section. Tightly stretched membranes enclose one or both ends, and are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums with tubular bodies consisting of a cylindrical upper section and a conical lower section. These drums have single tightly stretched membranes and the opposite ends are open. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

An individual drum with a tubular body consisting of a cylindrical upper section and a conical lower section. It is enclosed at one end by a single tightly stretched membrane and the opposite end is open. Sometimes the foot is flared. The membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Sets of drums with tubular bodies consisting of a cylindrical upper section and a conical lower section. Each drum body is enclosed at one end by a single tightly stretched membrane, and the opposite end is open. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums with tubular bodies consisting of a cylindrical upper section and a conical lower section. They are enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

An individual drum with a tubular body consisting of a cylindrical upper section and a conical lower section. It is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.272.11 Individual double-skin cylindro-conical drums, one skin used for playing
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a tubular body consisting of a cylindrical upper section and a conical lower section. It is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. One membrane is directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. Uganda drum.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.272.12 Individual double-skin cylindro-conical drums, both heads played
skos:Concept.skos:definition: An individual drum with a tubular body consisting of a cylindrical upper section and a conical lower section. It is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. Both membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Sets of drums with tubular bodies consisting of a cylindrical upper section and a conical lower section. Tightly stretched membranes enclose each drum body at either end. The membranes are directly struck by the player using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.272.21 Sets of double-skin cylindro-conical drums with single playing heads
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of drums with tubular bodies consisting of a cylindrical upper section and a conical lower section. They are enclosed at both ends by a tightly stretched membrane only one of which is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.272.22 Sets of double-skin cylindro-conical drums, both heads played
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of drums with tubular bodies consisting of a cylindrical upper section and a conical lower section. They are enclosed at either end by a tightly stretched membrane. Both membranes are directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Tubular drums with waisted bodies. The upper section is conical, and the lower section is rectilinear or curvilinear in profile, and tapers towards the open foot that may be flared. The tightly stretched single membrane is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. The tightly stretched membranes are directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. The body has no rigid handle. The tightly stretched membranes are directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. The body has no rigid handle. The single tightly stretched membrane is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. Tambourine.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.311-7 Single-skin frame drums without handle with membrane nailed to drum
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. The body has no rigid handle. The single tightly stretched membrane is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane nailed to drum.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.311-86 Single-skin frame drums without handle with cord-and-peg bracing
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. The body has no rigid handle. The single tightly stretched membrane is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane laced to drum. Cord-and-peg bracing. the cords are lsced at the lower end to pegs stuck into the wall of the drum. Africa.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.311-92 Single-skin frame drums without handle with membrane lapped onto a hoop
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. The body has no rigid handle. The single tightly stretched membrane is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane lapped onto a hoop.

Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. The body has no rigid handle. It is enclosed by two tightly stretched membranes that are directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. North Africa, Portugal.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.312-7 Double-skin frame drums without handle with membrane nailed to drum
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. The body has no rigid handle. It is enclosed by two tightly stretched membranes that are directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane nailed to drum.

Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The tightly stretched membranes are directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks.

Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The single tightly stretched membrane is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. Inuit.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.321-86 Single-skin frame drums with handle with cord-and-peg bracing
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The single tightly stretched membrane is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane laced to drum.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 211.321-92 Single-skin frame drums with handle with membrane lapped onto a hoop
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The single tightly stretched membrane is directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. With membrane lapped onto a hoop.

Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The body is enclosed by tightly stretched membranes that are directly struck by the player, using the hands or intermediate devices such as sticks. Tibet.
Tightly stretched membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

Drums with single tightly stretched membranes enclosing drum bodies in the form of vessels that are curvilinear or rectilinear in profile. The membranes are indirectly struck by enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken. (Unknown).
Drums with tubular bodies and tightly stretched membranes enclosing both ends. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

Drums with tubular bodies that have the same diameter at the middle and the ends. The drum bodies are enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

An individual drum with a tubular body that has the same diameter at the middle and the ends. The drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have the same diameter at the middle and the ends. Each drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

Drums with barrel-shaped bodies, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. The drum bodies are enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

An individual drum with a barrel-shaped body in which the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. The drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

Sets of drums with barrel-shaped bodies, where the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends. Each drum body is enclosed by a tightly stretched membrane at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

Drums with tubular bodies that have a larger diameter at the middle than at the ends. The drum bodies are rectilinear, with an angular profile. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken. (Unknown).

An individual drum with a tubular body that has a larger diameter at the middle than at the ends. The drum body is rectilinear, with an angular profile. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have a larger diameter at the middle than at the ends. The drum bodies are rectilinear, with an angular profile. Tightly stretched membranes enclose each drum body at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

Drums with tubular bodies that have a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

An individual drum with a tubular body that has a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose the body at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken. India.

Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose each drum body at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 212.242-7 Sets of hourglass-shaped rattle drums with membrane nailed to drum
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose each drum body at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken. With membrane nailed to drum.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 212.242-91 Sets of hourglass-shaped rattle drums with membrane lapped onto a ring of cord
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of drums with tubular bodies that have a smaller diameter at the middle than at the ends. Tightly stretched membranes enclose each drum body at either end. The membranes are indirectly struck by pendant pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken. With membrane lapped onto a ring of cord.

Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The tightly stretched membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The single tightly stretched membrane is indirectly struck by pendant pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 212.31-92 Single-skin frame rattle drums with membrane lapped onto a hoop
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The single tightly stretched membrane is indirectly struck by pendant pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken. With membrane lapped onto a hoop.

Drums in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The tightly stretched membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken.

An individual drum in which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle is attached to the frame in line with its diameter. The tightly stretched membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken. India.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 212.322 Sets of double-skin frame rattle drums
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Sets of drums in each one of which the depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane. A stick forming a handle passes through all the drum bodies. The tightly stretched membranes are indirectly struck by pendant or enclosed pellets, or similar objects, when the drum is shaken. China.
The sound is excited by tightly stretched membranes made to vibrate by friction.
The sound is excited by tightly stretched membranes, made to vibrate by friction. A stick in contact with the membrane is either itself rubbed, or is employed to rub the membrane.
The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by friction with a stick that passes through a hole in it. The stick is either itself rubbed, or is employed to rub the membrane.
