The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane, made to vibrate by friction. A fixed stick makes contact with the membrane, passing through a hole in it. The stick is subjected to friction by rubbing. Africa.

The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by friction with a stick that passes through a hole in it. The stick is movable to a sufficient extent to rub the membrane when it is itself rubbed by the hand. Africa.

The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by friction with a stick that passes through a hole in it. The stick can be moved freely; it is not itself rubbed, but is employed to rub the membrane. Venezuela.

The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by friction. A stick makes contact with the membrane, passing through a hole in it. The stick is tied to the membrane in an upright position. Europe.
The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by friction. A cord attached to the membrane is rubbed.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 232.1 Stationary friction drums with friction cord
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The sound is excited by tightly stretched membranes made to vibrate by friction. A cord, attached to the membrane, is rubbed. The drum is held stationary. Europe, Africa.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 232.11 Single-skin stationary drums with friction cord
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The sound is excited by a tightly stretched single membrane made to vibrate by friction when a cord, attached to the membrane is rubbed. The drum is held stationary.
The sound is excited by two tightly stretched membranes made to vibrate by friction when a cord, attached to them, is rubbed. The drum is held stationary.

The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by friction. The drum is whirled on a cord which rubs on a [resined] notch in the holding stick. Waldteufel [cardboard buzzer]. Europe, India, E. Africa.
The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by friction when rubbed by the hand.
The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by speaking or singing into it; the sound of the membrane modifies that of the voice. Europe, W. Africa.

The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by speaking or singing into it; the sound of the membrane modifies that of the voice. The membrane is incited directly, without the wind first passing through a chamber. Comb-and-paper.

The sound is excited by a tightly stretched membrane made to vibrate by speaking or singing into it; the sound of the membrane modifies that of the voice. The membrane is placed on top of a tube or box. Africa; while also, E. Asian flutes with a lateral hole sealed by a membrane, exhibit an affinity with the principle of the tube kazoo.
One or more strings are stretched between fixed points.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is bar-shaped; it may be a board placed edgewise.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved).

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The strings are cut from the bark of the cane, remaining attached at each end.

A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is cut from the bark of the cane, remaining attached at each end. New Guinea (Sepik R.), Togo.

Several strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The strings are cut from the bark of the cane, remaining attached at each end. They pass over a toothed stick or bridge. W. Africa (Fan).

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The strings are of separate material from the string bearer.

A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the string bearer.

A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, and it has no resonator. (The human mouth is not to be taken into account as a resonator.) The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the string bearer. NB: if a separate, unattached resonator is used, the specimen belongs to 311.121.21.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 311.121.11 Mono-heterochord musical bows without resonator or tuning noose
skos:Concept.skos:definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, and it has no tuning noose or resonator. (The human mouth is not to be taken into account as a resonator.) The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the string bearer. Africa (ganza, samuius, to).

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 311.121.12 Mono-heterochord musical bows without resonator, with tuning noose
skos:Concept.skos:definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, and it has no resonator. (The human mouth is not to be taken into account as a resonator.) The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the string bearer. A fibre noose is passed round the string, dividing it into two sections. South-equatorial Africa (nkungo, uta).

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 311.121.1-5 Mono-heterochord musical bows without resonator sounded by the bare fingers
skos:Concept.skos:definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, and it has no resonator. (The human mouth is not to be taken into account as a resonator.) The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the string bearer. Sounded by the bare fingers.

A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral, and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the string bearer.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 311.121.21 Mono-heterochord musical bows with independent resonator
skos:Concept.skos:definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer with an independent resonator. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the string bearer. Borneo (busoi).

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 311.121.22 Mono-heterochord musical bows with resonator attached
skos:Concept.skos:definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer with a resonator that can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the string bearer.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 311.121.221 Mono-heterochord musical bows with resonator attached, without tuning noose
skos:Concept.skos:definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer with a resonator that can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the string bearer. The string has no tuning noose. S. Africa (hade, thomo).

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 311.121.222 Mono-heterochord musical bows with resonator attached with tuning noose
skos:Concept.skos:definition: A single string is stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer with a resonator that can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The string is of separate material from the bearer. A fibre noose is passed round the string, dividing it into two sections. S. Africa, Madagascar (gubo, hungo, bobre).

Several strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The strings are of separate material from the string bearer.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 311.122.1 Poly-heterochord musical bows without tuning noose
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Several strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The strings are of separate material from the string bearer. The strings have no tuning noose. Oceania (kalove).

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 311.122.2 Poly-heterochord musical bows with tuning noose
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Several strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is flexible (and curved). The strings are of separate material from the string bearer. A fibre noose is passed round the strings, dividing them into two sections. Oceania (pagolo).

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string carrier is rigid.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is a stick with one flexible, curved end. India NB Stick zithers with both ends flexible and curved, like the Basuto bow, are counted as musical bows.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string carrier is a rigid stick. NB Round sticks which happen to be hollow by chance do not belong on this account to the tube zithers, but are round bar zithers; however, instruments in which a tubular cavity is employed as a true resonator, like the modern Mexican harpa, are tube zithers.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 311.221 (True) stick zithers with one resonator gourd
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer with one gourd resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is a rigid stick. India (tuila), Celebes (suleppe).

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 311.222 (True) stick zithers with several resonator gourds
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a string bearer with several gourd resonators which are not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is a rigid stick. India (vina).

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid string bearer, or of a rigid string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is a vaulted surface.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid string bearer, or of a rigid string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is a complete tube.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid string bearer, or of a rigid string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is a complete tube. The strings are cut from the bark of the tube, remaining attached at each end. Africa and Indonesia (gonra, togo, valiha).

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid string bearer, or of a rigid string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is a complete tube. The strings are of separate material from the tube.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 312.121 Heterochord (true) tube zithers without extra resonator
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid string bearer which is a complete tube. The strings are of separate material from the tube. The instrument has no additional resonator. S.E.Asia (alligator).

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 312.122 Heterochord (true) tube zithers with extra resonator
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid tubular string bearer that is an internode length of bamboo. It is placed inside a resonator which is a palm leaf tied in the shape of a bowl. The resonator is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The strings are of separate material from the string bearer. Timor.
One or more strings are stretched between fixed points along the convex surface of a gutter.
One or more strings are stretched between fixed points along the convex surface of a gutter. The strings are cut from the bark of the string bearer, remaining attached at each end. Flores.
One or more strings are stretched between fixed points along the convex surface of a gutter. The strings are of separate material from the string bearer. E. Asia.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid string bearer, or of a rigid string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is composed of canes tied together in the manner of a raft.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid string bearer, or of a rigid string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is composed of canes tied together in the manner of a raft. The strings are cut from the bark of the string bearer, remaining attached at each end. India, Upper Guinea, Central Congo.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid string bearer, or of a rigid string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is composed of canes tied together in the manner of a raft. The strings are of separate material from the string bearer. N. Malawi region.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 313.2-5 Heterochord raft zithers sounded by the bare fingers
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The instrument consists of a rigid string bearer, or of a rigid string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The string bearer is composed of canes tied together in the manner of a raft. The strings are of separate material from the string bearer. Sounded by the bare fingers.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, or a board with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The ground too, is to be counted as a string bearer.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, or a board with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer.
One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, without a resonator. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. Borneo.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 314.11-4-8 True board zithers without resonator sounded by hammers or beaters, with keyboard
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, without a resonator. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. Sounded by hammers or beaters. With keyboard.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 314.11-4-8+421.132-62-8 True board zithers without resonator, sounded by hammers or beaters, with keyboard + Sets of free reeds, with flexible air reservoir, with keyboard

skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 314.121 True board zithers with resonator bowl
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a bowl-shaped resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The resonator is a fruit shell or similar object, or an artificially carved equivalent. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 314.121-9 Mechanically driven true board zithers with resonator bowl
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a bowl-shaped resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The resonator is a fruit shell or similar object, or an artificially carved equivalent. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. With mechanical drive.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 314.122 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither)
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a box-shaped resonator made of slats which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. Zither, Hackbrett, pianoforte. NB This is true of the early piano only; modern pianos have no bottom and are board zithers. Harpsichords and some clavichords are box zithers.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 314.122-3 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) sounded by blowing
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a box-shaped resonator made of slats which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. Sounded by blowing.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 314.122-4 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) sounded by hammers or beaters
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a box-shaped resonator made of slats which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. Sounded by hammers or beaters.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 314.122-4-8 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) sounded by hammers or beaters, with keyboard
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a box-shaped resonator made of slats which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. Sounded by hammers or beaters. With keyboard.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 314.122-5 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) sounded by the bare fingers
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a box-shaped resonator made of slats which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. Sounded by the bare fingers.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 314.122-6 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) sounded by plectrum
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a box-shaped resonator made of slats which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. Sounded by plectrum.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 314.122-6-8 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) sounded by plectrum, with keyboard
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a box-shaped resonator made of slats which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. Sounded by plectrum. With keyboard.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 314.122-6-8+421.222-62-8 Boxzither, sounded by plectrum, with keyboard + set of duct flutes, with flexible air reservoir, with keyboard
314.122-8 True board zithers with resonator box (box zither) with keyboard
314.122-9 Mechanically driven true board zithers with resonator box (box zither)
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, with a box-shaped resonator made of slats which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer. With mechanical drive.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, or a board with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The plane of the strings is at right angles to the string bearer.
A single string is stretched between fixed points. The ground is the string bearer; there is only one string. The plane of the strings is at right angles to the string bearer. Malacca, Madagascar.

Several strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer is a rigid board, or a rigid board with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. The strings pass over a notched bridge. The plane of the strings is at right angles to the string bearer. Borneo, Africa: Bokongo, harp zither from the Bambinga people of the Uele district, Congo-Kinshasa.

Strings are stretched between fixed points across the mouth of a rigid trough. The strings are often formed from a single length threaded through several holes. The instrument may consist solely of a trough, or a trough with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. Tanzania.

Strings are stretched between fixed points across the mouth of a rigid trough. The strings are often formed from a single length threaded through several holes. The trough has no additional resonator.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 315.1-5 Trough zithers without resonator sounded by the bare fingers
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Strings are stretched between fixed points across the mouth of a rigid trough. The strings are often formed from a single length threaded through several holes. The trough has no additional resonator. Sounded by the bare fingers.

Strings are stretched between fixed points across the mouth of a rigid trough. The strings are often formed from a single length threaded through several holes. The trough has a gourd or a similar object as a resonator attached, which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus.

Strings are stretched between fixed points across a rigid open frame. The instrument may consist of a frame, or a frame with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus.
Strings are stretched between fixed points across a rigid open frame. The instrument has no resonator. Perhaps amongst medieval psalteries.

Strings are stretched between fixed points across a rigid open frame. The instrument has a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus. W. Africa, amongst the Kru (kani).
One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. Each string has its own flexible carrier. Africa (akam, kalangu, wambi).

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The strings are attached to a yoke which lies in the same plane as the sound-table and consists of two arms and a cross-bar.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The strings are attached to a yoke which lies in the same plane as the sound-table and consists of two arms and a cross-bar. A natural or carved-out bowl serves as the resonator. Lyra, E. African lyre.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 321.21-5 Bowl lyres sounded by the bare fingers
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The strings are attached to a yoke which lies in the same plane as the sound-table and consists of two arms and a cross-bar. A natural or carved-out bowl serves as the resonator. Sounded by the bare fingers.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The strings are attached to a yoke which lies in the same plane as the sound-table and consists of two arms and a cross-bar. A built-up wooden box serves as the resonator. Kithara, crwth.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle. Subsidiary necks, as e.g. in the Indian prasarini vina are disregarded, as also are lutes with strings distributed over several necks, like the harpolyre, and those like the lyre-guitars, in which the yoke is merely ornamental.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that passes diametrically through or over the resonator.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that passes diametrically through or over the resonator that consists of a natural or carved-out bowl. Iran, India, Indonesia.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 321.311-7 Spike bowl lutes sounded by bowing
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that passes diametrically through or over the resonator that consists of a natural or carved-out bowl. Sounded by bowing.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 321.312 Spike box lutes or spike guitars
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that passes diametrically through or over the resonator, which is built up from wood in the form of a box. Banjo, Egypt (rebab).

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 321.312-5 Spike box lutes or spike guitars sounded by the bare fingers
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that passes diametrically through or over the resonator, which is built up from wood in the form of a box. Sounded by the bare fingers.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 321.312-7 Spike box lutes or spike guitars sounded by bowing
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that passes diametrically through or over the resonator, which is built up from wood in the form of a box. Sounded by bowing.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that passes diametrically through the walls of the tubular resonator. China, Indochina.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 321.313-7 Spike tube lutes played by bowing

skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck. The resonator consists of a natural or carved-out bowl. Mandolin, theorbo.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 321.321-5 Necked bowl lutes sounded by the bare fingers
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck. The resonator consists of a natural or carved-out bowl. Sounded by the bare fingers.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 321.321-7 Necked bowl lutes sounded by bowing
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck. The resonator consists of a natural or carved-out bowl. Sounded by bowing.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 321.322 Necked box lutes or necked guitars
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck. The resonator is built up from wood in the form of a box. NB Lutes whose body is built up in the shape of a bowl are classified as bowl lutes. Violin, viol, guitar.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 321.322-5 Necked box lutes or necked guitars sounded by the bare fingers
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck. The resonator is built up from wood in the form of a box. Sounded by the bare fingers.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 321.322-7 Necked box lutes or necked guitars sounded by bowing
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck. The resonator is built up from wood in the form of a box. Sounded by bowing.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 321.322-71 Necked box lutes or necked guitars sounded by bowing with a bow
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck. The resonator is built up from wood in the form of a box. Sounded by bowing with a bow.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 321.322-8 Necked box lutes or necked guitars, with keyboard
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck. The resonator is built up from wood in the form of a box. With keyboard.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 321.322-9 Mechanically driven necked box lutes or necked guitars
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck. The resonator is built up from wood in the form of a box. With mechanical drive.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is neither attached to the resonator nor passes all the way through it, but terminates within the body. W.Africa.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is neither attached to the resonator nor passes all the way through it, but terminates within the body. The resonator consists of a natural or carved-out bowl.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table. The string bearer is a plain handle that is neither attached to the resonator nor passes all the way through it, but terminates within the body. The resonator is built up from wood in the form of a box.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has no pillar.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has no pillar. The neck curves away from the resonator. Burma and Africa.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has no pillar. The neck rests on the bottom of the resonator like a spoon in a cup. Uganda.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has no pillar. The tanged neck fits tightly into a hole at the narrow end of the resonator like a cork in a bottle. Democratic Republic of Congo, Zande, Nzakara, Banda, Mangebetu.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has no pillar. A carved finial extends from the resonator, usually in the form of a human head; it is often tied to the neck.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 322.11-5 Arched harps sounded by the bare fingers
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has no pillar. The neck curves away from the resonator. Sounded by the bare fingers.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has no pillar. The neck makes a sharp angle with the resonator. Assyria, Ancient Egypt, Ancient Korea, Mauretania ardin.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. There is no mechanism to alter the tuning of the harp while it is played. All medieval harps.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 322.211 Diatonic frame harps without tuning action
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. It is tuned diatonically. There is no mechanism to alter the tuning of the harp while it is played.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 322.212 Chromatic frame harps without tuning action
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. It is tuned chromatically. There is no mechanism to alter the tuning of the harp while it is played.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 322.212.1 Chromatic frame harps without tuning action, with the strings in one plane
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. It is tuned chromatically. There is no mechanism to alter the tuning of the harp while it is played. Most of the older chromatic harps.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 322.212.2 Chromatic frame harps without tuning action, with the strings in two planes crossing one another
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. It is tuned chromatically, with the strings in two planes crossing one another. The Lyon chromatic harp.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 322.212.3 Chromatic frame harps without tuning action, with the strings in two or more parallel planes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. It is tuned chromatically, with the strings in two or more parallel planes. Triple harp.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. The strings can be shortened by mechanical action.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. The strings can be shortened by mechanical hand-levers. Hook harp, dital harp, harpinella.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 322.221-5 Frame harps with manual action sounded by the bare fingers
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. The strings can be shortened by mechanical hand-levers. Sounded by the bare fingers.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. The tuning can be altered by pedals.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 322.222-5 Frame harps with pedal action sounded by the bare fingers
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck. The harp has a pillar. The tuning can be altered by pedals. Sounded by the bare fingers.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the soundtable; a tall stringholder or bridge holds the strings at successive levels, their sounding lengths increasing with their distance from the soundtable. The body resembles a spike lute, with a neck bisecting a calabash resonator.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 323.1 Arched spike harps with tall stringholders
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the soundtable. The strings are attached at different levels to a tall stringholder; their sounding lengths increasing with their distance from the soundtable. The body resembles a spike lute, with a neck bisecting a calabash resonator. The neck curves away from the resonator. Guinea (bolon), Gambia (simbango).

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 323.2 Spike harps with pressure bridges, bridge harps or harp-lutes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the soundtable. The strings pass over a tall notched bridge at successive levels, their sounding lengths increasing with their distance from the soundtable. The body, like a spike lute, has a string bearer that passes diametrically through the resonator. A line joining the lower ends of the strings would be perpendicular to the neck. Gambia, kora.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 323.2-5 Spike harps with pressure bridges, bridge harps or harp-lutes sounded by the bare fingers
skos:Concept.skos:definition: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the soundtable. The strings pass over a tall notched bridge at successive levels, their sounding lengths increasing with their distance from the soundtable. The body, like a spike lute, has a string bearer that passes diametrically through the resonator. A line joining the lower ends of the strings would be perpendicular to the neck. Sounded by the bare fingers.

One or more strings are stretched between fixed points. The string bearer and the resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the soundtable; a tall stringholder or bridge holds the strings at successive levels, their sounding lengths increasing with their distance from the soundtable. A carved extension of the resonator forms the socket for the shaft of the neck (illustrated in S.C. DeVale African Harps: Construction, Decoration and Sound Sounding Forms ed. M-T Brincard, [New York, 1989] p.56 figure 6.3a).

A single or double stretched string is fixed at one end to a handle. At the other end it is attached to a membrane covering a hole cut out of the base of a resonator, resembling a drum. The string bearer and resonator are organically united so that they cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the string lies at right angles to the membrane. By adjusting the handle, the player braces the string to alter its tension and change its pitch.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 331 Variable tension chordophones or 'plucked drums' with loose string attached to the drum-head
skos:Concept.skos:definition: A single or double stretched string is fixed at one end to a handle. At the other end it is attached to a membrane covering a hole cut out of the base of a resonator, resembling a drum. The string bearing handle and the resonator are united by the string so that they cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the string lies at right angles to the membrane. By adjusting the position of the handle, the player braces the loose string to alter its tension and change its pitch. India (anandalahari).

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 332 Variable tension chordophones or 'plucked drums' with string attached to the end of a neck and to the drum-head
skos:Concept.skos:definition: A single string is stretched between two fixed points. At one end it is attached to a handle in the form of a neck or yoke. At the other end it is fixed to a membrane covering a hole cut out of the base of a resonator, resembling a drum. The string bearer and resonator are organically united so that they cannot be separated without destroying the instrument. The plane of the string lies at right angles to the membrane. By adjusting the handle, the player braces the string to alter its tension and change its pitch. India (gopi yantra).
The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. In this group also are classed those reed instruments sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. In this group also are classed those reed instruments sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator.The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air-stream meets a sharp edge, or a sharp edge is moved through the air. In either case a periodic displacement of air occurs to alternate flanks of the edge. Whip, sword-blade.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. In this group also are classed those reed instruments sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air-stream is interrupted periodically.

Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air-stream is directed against a lamella, setting it in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamella.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 412.11 Idiophonic interruptive aerophones or reeds: paired reeds
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air-stream is directed against a lamella, setting it in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. Two lamellae make a gap which closes periodically during their vibration. A split grass-blade.

Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air-stream is directed against a lamella, setting it in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. A lamella periodically opens and closes an aperture. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamella.

Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. In individual beating reeds the air-stream is directed against a single lamella, setting it in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamella periodically opens and closes an aperture. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamella. The reed may have a resonator in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes. British Columbia.

Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. In sets of beating reeds the air-stream is directed against a set of lamellae, setting them in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamellae periodically open and close a set of apertures. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamellae. Such reeds may have a resonator, in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes. The earlier reed stops of organs.

Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. The air-stream is directed against a lamella, setting it in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamella vibrates through a closely-fitting slot. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamella. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. Each reed may have a resonator in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes.

Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. In individual free reeds the air-stream is directed against a single lamella, setting it in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamella vibrates through a closely-fitting slot. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamella. Such reeds may have a resonator in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes. Single-note motor horn.

Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. In sets of free reeds the air-stream is directed against a set of lamellae, setting them in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamellae vibrate through a closely-fitting slot. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamellae. Each reed may have a resonator in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes. NB In instruments like the Chinese sheng, where the bamboo pipes act as an acoustic coupler, the fingerholes do not serve to modify the pitch and are therefore not equivalent to the fingerholes of other pipes. Reed organ, mouthorgan, accordion.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 412.132-62 Sets of free reeds with flexible air reservoir
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. In sets of free reeds the air-stream is directed against a set of lamellae, setting them in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamellae vibrate through a closely-fitting slot. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamellae. Each reed may have a resonator in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes. With flexible air reservoir.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 412.132-62-8 Sets of free reeds with flexible air reservoir, with keyboard
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. In sets of free reeds the air-stream is directed against a set of lamellae, setting them in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamellae vibrate through a closely-fitting slot. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamellae. Each reed may have a resonator in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound. The instrument has a flexible air reservoir. The mechanism admitting air to the reeds is operated by a keyboard.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 412.132-6-9 Mechanically driven sets of free reeds with air reservoir
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. In sets of free reeds the air-stream is directed against a set of lamellae, setting them in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamellae vibrate through a closely-fitting slot. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamellae. Each reed may have a resonator in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes. With air reservoir. With mechanical drive.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 412.132-9 Mechanically driven sets of free reeds
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. In sets of free reeds the air-stream is directed against a set of lamellae, setting them in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamellae vibrate through a closely-fitting slot. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamellae. Each reed may have a resonator in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes. With mechanical drive.

Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air-stream is directed against the edge of a stretched band or ribbon. The acoustics of this process have not yet been studied. British Columbia.

Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The reeds are of grass and similar stems with longitudinal slits.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 412.1-9 Mechanically driven idiophonic interruptive aerophones or reeds
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air-stream is directed against a lamella, setting it in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamella. With mechanical drive.
The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The interruptive agent is not a reed.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The interruptive agent is not a reed.The interruptive agent rotates in its own plane. Sirens, whirring disc.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The interruptive agent is not a reed.The interruptive agent turns on its axis. Bull-roarer, ventilating fan.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 412-122-8 Sets of beating reeds with keyboard
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Reed instruments that are free aerophones are sounded by a flow of air in which the reed is the primary vibrator. In sets of beating reeds the air-stream is directed against a set of lamellae, setting them in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. The lamellae periodically open and close a set of apertures. The instrument is tuned by mechanical action on the lamellae. Such reeds may have a resonator, in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes. With a keyboard.
The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air is made to vibrate by a single density stimulus condensation shock.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air is made to vibrate by a single density stimulus condensation shock when it is forced out. Pop guns.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument. The air is made to vibrate by a single density stimulus condensation shock when it is forced in. W.Africa, shantu.
The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 420 Edge-tone instruments that are not flutes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The hole through which the instrument is blown opens onto a narrow chamber, and has an exit hole diametrically opposite it. Widgeon whistles.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow stream of air is directed against an edge to excite a column of air in a tube or a body of air in a cavity.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow stream of air is directed against an edge. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a tube.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a single tube.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a single tube. The lower end of the flute is open.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.111.11 Open single end-blown flutes without fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a single tube. The lower end of the flute is open. The instrument has no fingerholes. Bengal.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.111.12 Open single end-blown flutes with fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a single tube. The lower end of the flute is open. The instrument has fingerholes. Almost world-wide.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a single tube. The lower end of the flute is closed.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.111.21 Stopped single end-blown flutes without fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a single tube. The lower end of the flute is closed. The instrument has no fingerholes. The bore of a key.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.111.211 Stopped end-blown flutes without fingerholes used in sets
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a single tube. The lower end of the flute is closed. The instrument has no fingerholes. Several instruments are played together. Lithuania, S.Africa Venda and others.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.111.22 Stopped single end-blown flutes with fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a single tube. The lower end of the flute is closed. The instrument has fingerholes. Especially New Guinea.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a single tube. The lower end of the flute is partly closed.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.111.31 Partly-stopped single end-blown flutes without fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a single tube. The lower end of the flute is partly closed. The instrument has no fingerholes.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.111.32 Partly-stopped single end-blown flutes with fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a single tube. The lower end of the flute is partly closed. The instrument has fingerholes.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.112 Sets of end-blown flutes or panpipes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a tube. Several end-blown flutes of different pitch are combined to form a single instrument.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a t

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a tube. Several end-blown flutes of different pitch are combined to form a single instrument. The lower ends of the pipes are open. The pipes are tied together in the form of a board, or they are made by drilling tubes in a board. China.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a tube. Several end-blown flutes of different pitch are combined to form a single instrument. The lower ends of the pipes are open. The pipes are tied together in a round bundle. Solomon Is., New Britain, New Ireland, Admiralty Is.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a tube. Several end-blown flutes of different pitch are combined to form a single instrument. The lower ends of the pipes are closed. Europe, S. America.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a tube. Several end-blown flutes of different pitch are combined to form a single instrument. Some of the pipes have open lower ends, others are closed. Solomon Is., S. America.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a tube.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a single tube.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a tube. The distal end of the flute is open.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a tube. The distal end of the flute is open. The instrument has no fingerholes. S. W. Timor.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a tube. The distal end of the flute is open. The instrument has fingerholes. European flute.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a tube. The distal end of the tube is a natural node of the pipe pierced by a small hole. N. W. Borneo.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a tube. The distal end of the tube is stopped.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a tube. The distal end of the tube is stopped. The instrument has no fingerholes.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.121.311 Stopped side-blown flutes without fingerholes, with fixed stopped lower end
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a tube. The distal end of the tube has a fixed stopper. The instrument has no fingerholes. Apparently non-existent.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.121.312 Stopped side-blown flutes without fingerholes, adjustable stopped lower end
skos:Concept.skos:definition: Stopped side-blown flutes without fingerholes, with adjustable stopped lower end (piston flutes) The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a tube. The distal end of the tube has an adjustable stopper. The instrument has no fingerholes. (piston flutes) Malacca, New Guinea.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a tube. The distal end of the tube is stopped. The instrument has fingerholes. E. Bengal, Malacca.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow stream of air is directed against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of the tube. Two or more flutes are played together.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where narrow stream of air is directed against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of the tube. Two or more flutes are played together. The distal ends of the flutes are open. Chamber flute-orum.

Sets of stopped side-blown flutes The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow stream of air is directed against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of the tube. Two or more flutes are played together. The distal ends of the flutes are closed. N. W. Brazil (among the Siusi).

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow stream of air is directed against an edge as the player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of a vessel. Brazil (Karaja), Lower Congo (Bafiote).

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the notch at the upper open end of a tube.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the notch at the upper open end of a single tube.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the notch at the upper open end of a single tube. The lower end of the flute is open.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.141.11 Open single notch flutes without fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the notch at the upper open end of a single tube. The lower end of the flute is open. The instrument has no fingerholes.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.141.12 Open single notch flutes with fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the notch at the upper open end of a single tube. The lower end of the flute is open. The instrument has fingerholes. E. Asia, S. America.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the notch at the upper open end of a single tube. The lower end of the flute is closed.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.141.21 Stopped single notch flutes without fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself.
