The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the notch at the upper open end of a single tube. The lower end of the flute is closed. The instrument has no fingerholes.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.141.211 Stopped notch flutes without fingerholes used in sets
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the notch at the upper open end of a single tube. The lower end of the flute is closed. The instrument has no fingerholes. Several instruments are played together.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.141.22 Stopped single notch flutes with fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the notch at the upper open end of a single tube. The lower end of the tube is closed. The instrument has fingerholes.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.142 Sets of notch flutes or panpipes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the notch at the upper open end of a tube. Several notch flutes of different pitch are combined to form a single instrument.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.142.1 Open sets of notch-flutes or panpipes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the notch at the upper open end of a tube. Several notch flutes of different pitch are combined to form a single instrument. The lower ends of the pipes are open.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.142.2 Stopped sets of notch-flutes or panpipes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his/her lips, blowing against the notch at the upper open end of a tube. Several notch flutes of different pitch are combined to form a single instrument. The lower ends of the pipes are closed. Korea (so).

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.2 Flutes with duct or duct flutes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is outside the wall of the flute; this group includes flutes with the duct chamfered in the wall under a ring-like sleeve and other similar arrangements.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is outside the wall of the flute; this group includes flutes with the duct chamfered in the wall under a ring-like sleeve and other similar arrangements.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is outside the wall of the flute; this group includes flutes with the duct chamfered in the wall under a ring-like sleeve and other similar arrangements. The lower end of the flute is open.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.211.11 Open flutes with external duct without fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is outside the wall of the flute; this group includes flutes with the duct chamfered in the wall under a ring-like sleeve and other similar arrangements. The lower end of the flute is open. The instrument has no fingerholes. China, Borneo.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.211.12 Open flutes with external duct with fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is outside the wall of the flute; this group includes flutes with the duct chamfered in the wall under a ring-like sleeve and other similar arrangements. The lower end of the flute is open. The instrument has fingerholes. Indonesia.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is outside the wall of the flute; this group includes flutes with the duct chamfered in the wall under a ring-like sleeve and other similar arrangements. The lower end of the tube is a natural node of the pipe pierced by a small hole. Malacca.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is outside the wall of the flute; this group includes flutes with the duct chamfered in the wall under a ring-like sleeve and other similar arrangements. The lower end of the flute is closed.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.212 Sets of flutes with external duct
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. In each flute, a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is outside the wall of the flute; this group includes flutes with the duct chamfered in the wall under a ring-like sleeve and other similar arrangements. The flutes are joined to form a set. Tibet.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the single tube.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube. The lower end of the tube is open.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.221.11 Open flutes with internal duct without fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube. The lower end of the tube is open. The instrument has no fingerholes. European signalling whistle.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.221.12 Open flutes with internal duct with fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube. The lower end of the tube is open. The instrument has fingerholes. Recorder.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense.The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube. The lower end of the tube is a natural node of the pipe pierced by a small hole. India and Indonesia.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube. The lower end of the tube is closed.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.221.31 Stopped flutes with internal duct, without fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense.The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube. The lower end of the tube is closed. The instrument has no fingerholes.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.221.311 Stopped flutes with internal duct, without fingerholes with fixed stopped lower end
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube. The lower end of the tube is has a fixed stopper. The instrument has no fingerholes. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is inside the tube. The lower end of the tube is closed. The instrument has fingerholes. Morocco.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.221.41 Vessel flutes with duct, without fingerholes

A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The body of the flute is in the form of a vessel, without fingerholes. Zoomorphic pottery whistles (Europe, Asia).

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.221.42 Vessel flutes with duct, with fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense.The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The body of the flute is in the form of a vessel, with fingerholes.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.221.421 Vessel flutes with duct, with single fingerhole
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The body of the flute is in the form of a vessel, with a single fingerhole. Dog whistles etc.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.221.422 Vessel flutes with duct, with two or more fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense.The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The body of the flute is in the form of a vessel, with two or more fingerholes. Ocarina.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.222 Sets of flutes with internal duct

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.222.1 Sets of open flutes with internal duct
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The opposite end is open. Two or more flutes are combined to form a set.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.222.11 Sets of open flutes with internal duct without fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The opposite end is open. Two or more flutes are combined to form a set. The instrument has no fingerholes. Open flue stops of the organ.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.222.11+421.222.3 Sets of open flutes with internal duct without fingerholes combined with set of partly-stopped flutes with internal duct
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. Two or more pipes with open end are combined with two more more pipes with closed end. The instrument has no fingerholes. Organ with both open flue and Rohrflote stops.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.222.11+421.222.3-8 Sets of open flutes with internal duct without fingerholes combined with set of partly-stopped flutes with internal duct with keyboard
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. Two or more pipes with open end are combined with two more more pipes with closed end. The instrument has no fingerholes. With keyboard.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.222.11-9 Mechanically driven sets of open flutes with internal duct without fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The opposite end is open. Two or more flutes are combined to form a set. The instrument has no fingerholes. With mechanical drive.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.222.12 Sets of open flutes with internal duct with fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The opposite end is open. The instrument has fingerholes. Double flageolet.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.222.2 Sets of partly-stopped flutes with internal duct
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The opposite end is partly stopped. Two or more flutes are combined to form a set. Rohrflote stops of the organ.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.222.3 Sets of stopped flutes with internal duct
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The opposite end is closed. Two or more flutes are combined to form a set. Stopped flue stops of the organ.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.222.4 Sets of dissimilar flutes with internal duct
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within each flute, where a narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. Two or more flutes of more than one kind (open, partly-stopped or stopped) are combined to form a set.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 421.23 Flutes with duct formed by an internal baffle with an external cover
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice. The duct is formed by an internal baffle (natural node, block of resin) and an external tied-on cover (cane, wood, hide). American Plains, S.E.Asia, Indonesia.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a lamella. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem) which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.11 Single reedpipes with double (or quadruple) reeds
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The single pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.11.2-5 (Single) wind-cap oboes with cylindrical bore, with fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The single pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. The instrument has a cylindrical bore. The instrument has fingerholes. It is tuned by altering the length of the air column. With wind cap.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.11.2-62 (Single) oboes with cylindrical bore, with fingerholes with flexible air reservoir
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The single pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. The instrument has a cylindrical bore. The instrument has fingerholes. It is tuned by altering the length of the air column. With flexible air reservoir.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The single pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. The instrument has a cylindrical bore.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.111.1 (Single) oboes with cylindrical bore, without fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The single pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. The instrument has a cylindrical bore and is without fingerholes. British Columbia.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.111.2 (Single) oboes with cylindrical bore, with fingerholes
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The single pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. The instrument has a cylindrical bore. The instrument has fingerholes. It is tuned by altering the length of the air column. Aulos, crumhorn.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.111.2+422.211.1 Cylindrical double-reed chanter with stopped end + cylindrical single-reed drone
422.111.2+422.211.1-62 Cylindrical double-reed chanter with stopped end + cylindrical single-reed drone; flexible air reservoir
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The double-reed pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air and a cylindrical bore. In the single-reed reedpipe, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. With flexible air reservoir.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.111.2+422.22-62 Single oboes with cylindrical bore combined with a set of reedpipes with single reed with flexible air reservoir
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The double-reed pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air and a cylindrical bore. In each pipe of the set of single-reed reedpipes, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. With flexible air reservoir.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.111+422.211 Single oboes with cylindrical bore combined with a single reedpipe with single reed
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The double-reed pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air and a cylindrical bore. In the single-reed reedpipe, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. Cornemuse.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.111+422.22 Single oboes with cylindrical bore combined with a set of reedpipes with single reed
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The double-reed pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air and a cylindrical bore. In each pipe of the set of single-reed reedpipes, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. Northumbrian small-pipes, Scottish small-pipes.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The single pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. The instrument has a conical bore. It is tuned by altering the length of the air column. European oboe.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.112+422.111.2-71+422.22-62 Conical double-reed chanter + cylindrical double-reed regulator with stopped end with keys + set of cylindrical single-reed drones; flexible air reservoir
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The single pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. The single pipe has a conical bore with keys. Each pipe in the set of double-reed pipes has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air and a conical bore. In each single-reed pipe in the set of two or more, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. With flexible air reservoir.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.112+422.121.2-71+422.22-62 Conical double-reed chanter + set of cylindrical double-reed regulator with stopped end with keys + set of cylindrical single-reed drones; flexible air reservoir
422.112+422.122+422.22 Single oboes with conical bore combined with a set of oboes with conical bore and a set of reedpipes with single reeds
skos:Concept.skos:definition: e vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The single pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. The single pipe has a conical bore. Each pipe in the set of double-reed pipes has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air and a conical bore. In each single-reed pipe in the set of two or more, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. Irish Uillean bagpipes.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.112+422.122-71+422.22-62 Single oboes with conical bore combined with a set of oboes with conical bore with keys and a set of reedpipes with single reeds with flexible air reservoir
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The single pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. The single pipe has a conical bore with keys. Each pipe in the set of double-reed pipes has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air and a conical bore. In each single-reed pipe in the set of two or more, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. With flexible air reservoir.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.112+422.211 Single oboes with conical bore combined with a single reedpipe with single reed
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The double-reed pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air and a conical bore. In the single-reed reedpipe, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. Biniou koz or petit biniou.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.112+422.211.1-62 Conical double-reed chanter + cylindrical single-reed drone; flexible air reservoir
422.112+422.22 Single oboes with conical bore combined with a set of reedpipes with single reeds
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The single pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. The single pipe has a conical bore. In each pipe in the set of two or more, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. Highland Scottish bagpipes, Lowland Scottish and Border bagpipes.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.112+422.22-62 Conical double-reed chanter + set of cylindrical single-reed drones; flexible air reservoir
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. The column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. The single pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. The single pipe has a conical bore. In each pipe in the set of two or more, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. With flexible air reservoir.

The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense. The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. Within each of the set of pipes, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. Each pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.121 Sets of oboes with cylindrical bore
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense.The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. Within each of the set of pipes, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. Each pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. The pipes have a cylindrical bore. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. Double aulos.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.121+422.22 Sets of oboes with cylindrical bore combined with a set of reedpipes with single reeds
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense.The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. Within each of the set of pipes, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. Each double-reed pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air and a cylindrical bore. In each single-reed pipe in the set of two or more, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. Musette de cours.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.121-71+422.22-62 Sets of oboes with cylindrical bore with keys combined with a set of reedpipes with single reeds with flexible air reservoir
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense.The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. Within each of the set of pipes, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. Each double-reed pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air and a cylindrical bore with keys. In each single-reed pipe in the set of two or more, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of a [single] 'reed' consisting of a lamella which periodically opens and closes an aperture, controlling the flow of air. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. With flexible air reservoir.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.122 Sets of oboes with conical bore
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense.The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. Within each of the set of pipes, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. Each pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. The pipes have a conical bore. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. India.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.122+422.121 Sets of oboes with conical bore combined with a set of oboes with cylindrical bore
skos:Concept.skos:definition: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense.The standing waves are significantly confined within the instrument itself. Within each of the set of pipes, the column of air is made to vibrate by the intermittent access of an air stream produced by means of lamellae. Each pipe has a reed of paired lamellae (usually a flattened stem), which periodically open and close, controlling the flow of air. There are two or more pipes with conical bore and two or more pipes with cyindricaal bore. The instrument is tuned by altering the lengths of the air columns. Zampogna.

skos:Concept.skos:prefLabel: 422.122+422.121-62 Set of conical double-reed chanters + set of cylindrical double-reed drones, flexible air reservoir
422.122+422.22 Sets of oboes with conical bore combined with a set of reedpipes with single reeds
